title: Product-Market Fit Crisis at HealthTrack
description: An early-stage health-tech startup with promising initial traction faces conflicting signals about product-market fit. As Head of Product, you must determine whether to pivot, persevere, or iterate.

persona.name: Marcus Johnson
persona.background: Former physician turned entrepreneur, deeply passionate about the mission
persona.personality: Visionary but can be defensive about the original vision. Needs data-driven arguments to change course.

briefing.situation:
HealthTrack is a 18-month-old startup building a platform to help primary care physicians coordinate care for patients with chronic conditions. The founding team includes 2 physicians and 2 engineers. You're the Head of Product, brought in 6 months ago to scale the product.

The company raised a $3M seed round 12 months ago. Current situation:
- 45 physician practices signed up (target was 200)
- Only 18 practices are 'active' (used in past 30 days)
- Among active practices, usage is mixed: some love it, some barely touch it
- Burn rate: $250K/month (12 months runway remaining)
- The CEO believes the problem is sales/marketing execution, not the product
- Your product instincts say something deeper is wrong

**Recent Developments:**
- A large hospital system expressed interest but wants completely different features
- Your most engaged users are using the product in ways you didn't intend
- Churn is 25% in the first 3 months
- NPS is 35 (mixed signals: promoters love it, detractors hate it)
- The original value proposition ("coordinate care seamlessly") isn't resonating in sales calls

The CEO has asked you to present at next week's board meeting: "Are we on track or do we need to pivot?"
objectives: Assess the current state of product-market fit using available signals
Identify the core disconnect between product vision and market reality
Recommend a specific path forward with supporting evidence

user_segmentation.description: User behavior analysis across practice types

data.primary_use_case: Trying to use for referral tracking (not designed for this)

feature_usage.description: Weekly active usage by feature (among active users)

insights: Solo practitioners: 'Too complex for my needs. I just want better patient communication.'
Small group advocate: 'The care plan templates save us hours. We built our diabetes program around them.'
Large group critic: 'We need this to integrate with our existing EMR. Also, we really need better referral management.'
Churned user: 'Seemed promising but the team coordination features never worked for our workflow.'
Power user: 'We've basically built a chronic care management program using your templates. Wish you had more disease-specific templates and better reporting for billing.'

data.emr_vendors: Dominican players like Epic/Cerner adding chronic care modules
data.care_coordination_platforms: 3-4 well-funded competitors focusing on hospital systems
data.chronic_care_management: Fragmented market with disease-specific solutions, lots of white space

challenges.title: Product-Market Fit Assessment
challenges.description: Based on the data provided, assess whether HealthTrack has achieved product-market fit. Support your conclusion with specific evidence. If fit is partial or unclear, identify which segments/use cases show strongest signals.

config.placeholder: Analyze the usage data, customer feedback, and market signals to assess PMF status...

challenges.title: Strategic Hypothesis
challenges.description: Develop a hypothesis about what's really going on. What is the true product-market fit opportunity that the data reveals? This may be different from the original vision. Explain your reasoning.

config.placeholder:
Based on the evidence, I believe the real opportunity is...

Supporting evidence:
1. ...
2. ...

This suggests we should...

challenges.title: Board Recommendation
challenges.description: Present your recommendation: Pivot, Persevere, or Iterate? Outline your specific plan including: (1) Target customer segment, (2) Core value proposition, (3) Key product changes needed, (4) Go-to-market adjustments, (5) Success metrics for next 6 months.

config.placeholder:
Recommendation: [Pivot/Persevere/Iterate]

Target Customer: ...

Value Proposition: ...

Product Changes:
1. ...

GTM Adjustments: ...

Success Metrics:
- ...

Risks: ...

strategic-thinking.description: Demonstrates ability to synthesize complex signals, form coherent hypotheses, and develop strategic frameworks

scoring.5: Exceptional strategic synthesis. Correctly identifies the core PMF signal (care plan templates for chronic care management). Develops clear hypothesis connecting user behavior to market opportunity. Strategic recommendation is well-reasoned and addresses root issues.
scoring.4: Strong strategic thinking. Identifies key patterns in the data and develops reasonable hypothesis. Recommendation addresses core issues though may miss some nuances.
scoring.3: Adequate analysis. Recognizes some key signals but synthesis may be incomplete. Hypothesis is reasonable but not deeply insightful. Recommendation is logical but generic.
scoring.2: Limited strategic thinking. Fails to synthesize data effectively. Hypothesis is weak or unsupported. Recommendation doesn't address core issues.
scoring.1: Poor strategic analysis. Misinterprets signals or fails to form coherent view. Recommendation is disconnected from evidence.

market-awareness.description: Shows understanding of market dynamics, customer needs, competitive landscape, and go-to-market considerations

scoring.5: Excellent market awareness. Correctly identifies underserved segment (small group chronic care management). Understands competitive dynamics and white space. GTM recommendations are specific and realistic.
scoring.4: Good market understanding. Identifies viable segment and understands competitive context. GTM approach is reasonable with some specifics.
scoring.3: Adequate market awareness. General understanding of market but lacks specific insights. GTM approach is generic or partially developed.
scoring.2: Limited market awareness. Superficial understanding of customer needs or competitive dynamics. GTM approach is vague or unrealistic.
scoring.1: Poor market understanding. Fails to analyze market meaningfully or makes incorrect assumptions.

leadership-judgment.description: Shows sound judgment in making difficult strategic decisions, managing organizational change, and setting realistic goals

scoring.5: Excellent judgment. Makes clear recommendation while acknowledging trade-offs. Realistic about organizational challenges of pivot/change. Success metrics are specific and appropriate. Addresses CEO's likely concerns thoughtfully.
scoring.4: Good judgment. Clear recommendation with reasonable supporting logic. Some consideration of organizational factors. Success metrics are relevant.
scoring.3: Adequate judgment. Makes a recommendation but may not fully address complexity. Limited consideration of organizational factors or change management.
scoring.2: Limited judgment. Recommendation may be too cautious or too bold without proper justification. Weak consideration of organizational reality.
scoring.1: Poor judgment. Unrealistic recommendation or fails to make a clear choice. No consideration of organizational factors.
